clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of the Effectiveness and Safety of Sustained-release Hydromorphone (a Strong Opioid) in Patients With Chronic Noncancer Pain.
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Open-Label, Comparative Parallel Group Study to Assess Efficacy and Safety on Flexible Dosages of OROS Hydromorphone Once-Daily Compared to Sustained Release Oxycodone Twice Daily in Subjects With Chronic Non-malignant Pain Requiring Continuous Opioid Therapy.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness and safety of sustained- release hydromorphone, formulated to release slowly over time, taken once daily, and controlled- release oxycodone taken twice daily, in patients with chronic non-cancer pain. The study will also determine the dose of sustained-release hydromorphone that provides a level of pain control that is equal to the pain control provided by control-released oxycodone (equi-analgesic dosage).

detailed_description.textblock:
Conventional immediate-release forms of hydromorphone and oxycodone have a relatively short duration of action that require dosing every 4 to 6 hours. To counterbalance the drawback of repeated opioid intake, sustained-release formulations of oxycodone and hydromorphone were developed that allow twice-daily dosing. Subsequently, a novel, once-daily, extended-release hydromorphone formulation was developed to further enhance ease of treatment and improve effectiveness in the treatment of severe pain. This is a randomized, open-label, comparative, parallel-group, 24-week flexible-dose study in patients with chronic noncancer pain severe enough to require continuous opioid therapy. Patients will receive either 8 mg of sustained-release hydromorphone, taken once daily or 10 mg of controlled-release oxycodone, taken twice daily. Individual adjustments in dosing will be performed to achieve satisfactory pain control, up to a maximum daily dosage of 32 mg for hydromorphone and 80 mg for oxycodone. The primary efficacy outcome will be the determination of the dose of hydromorphone that produces a level of pain control that is equal to the pain control provided by oxycodone (equi-analgesic dose). Safety will be monitored throughout the study. The study hypothesis is that sustained-release hydromorphone taken once daily is well tolerated and is not inferior with regard to pain control to controlled-release oxycodone taken twice daily.
Amendment:
Amendment was made to the duration of the study from duration of '24 weeks' to '52 weeks' in order to collect long-term safety and efficacy data. OROS hydromorphone 8, 16, or 32 mg tablets QD or SR oxycodone 10, 20, or 40 mg tablets BID. Individual adjustments in dosing performed to achieve satisfactory pain control over 24 weeks. Amendment: treatment duration was extended to 52 weeks.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Per Protocol [PP] Population)
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with sustained release (SR) oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in BPI Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Intent to Treat [ITT] Population)
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with SR oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".

primary_outcome.measure: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (PP Population)
primary_outcome.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.

primary_outcome.measure: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (ITT Population)
primary_outcome.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.
Dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control at steady state, defined as the mean dose from week 4 to week 24.

primary_outcome.measure: Equi-analgesic Dose at Steady State (ITT Population)
primary_outcome.description: Dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control at steady state, defined as the mean dose from week 4 to week 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in BPI Pain Severity Sub-score "Pain at Its Worst" (BPI Item 3) at Week 24 (ITT Population)
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in BPI pain severity, pain at its worst (BPI item 3) assessed using the BPI questionnaire. Score values ranges from 0 (no pain) to 10 (pain as bad as you can imagine). Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain at its worst".

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) questionnaire at week 24, specifically the sleep subscale index I. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improved sleep quality.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Evening Mean Pain Score "Pain Right Now" at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now". Subjects rated the severity of "pain right now" on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now".

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Morning Mean Pain Score "Pain Right Now" at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary morning mean pain score "pain right now". Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now".

secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects with dose increase in study medication.

BPI items 3 to 6, score range 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine; BPI items 9a to 9g, score range from 0 to 10, where 0 = does not interfere and 10 = completely interferes. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain severity and pain interference. BPI item 8, score range from 0 to 100, where 0 = no relief and 100 = complete relief. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain relief.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index I) at Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items; MOS sleep scale index I (average of item 1, 3, 7, 8, 9, and 12) was assessed at week 4. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index II) at Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items. MOS index II (average of items 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 12) was assessed at week 4. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index II) at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items. secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Somnolence at Week 24

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects Indicating That They Had Optimal Sleep at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects indicating that they had optimal sleep was assessed based on the number of hours of sleep reported on the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Optimal sleep was defined as 7 to 8 hours sleep per night.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality at Week 52
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 52. Score range 0 to 100. For disturbance, snoring, shortness of breath or headache, and somnolence, 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality; negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality for these measures. For adequacy and quantity, 0 = worst sleep quality and 100 = best sleep quality; positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality for these measures.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects Indicating Optimal Sleep at Week 52
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects who experienced optimal sleep was assessed based on the number of hours of sleep reported on the MOS questionnaire at week 52. Optimal sleep was defined as 7-8 hours sleep per night.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Mean Pain Evening, Morning, and All Day Scores at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary evening, morning and all day mean pain scores for pain right now, at its worst, at its least, and average. Subjects rated the severity of pain on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary mean pain scores.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Mean Pain Score for "Pain at Its Worst" From Morning to Evening at Weeks 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, and 24

Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary mean pain score "pain at its worst".

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Dose of Study Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects with change in dose of study treatment was assessed at weeks 4, 24, and 52.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Dose of Study Treatment During Titration Phase (First 4 Weeks of Study) and Overall Treatment Phase I (First 24 Weeks of Study)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subejcts with change in dose of study treatment was assessed and stratified by time on study, at least 4 weeks versus dropped out at highest dose before week 4, at weeks 4 and 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Drop-outs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline to week 24 (core); week 24 to week 52 (extension)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of drop-outs according to reasons for drop-out and due to inefficacy at maximal dosage was assessed at weeks 24 and 52.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Days With add-on Pain Medication
secondary_outcome.description: Number of days with add-on pain medication during the first 24 weeks of the study was assessed at week 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amount of add-on Pain Medication
secondary_outcome.description: Total amount of add-on pain medication (paracetamol) for the first 24 weeks was assessed at week 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mode and Convenience of Drug Intake.
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects filled out a questionnaire based on the mode and convenience of drug intake and could rate their responses as very convenient, convenient, neither convenient or inconvenient, inconvenient, and very inconvenient.

secondary_outcome.measure: Resource Utilization of Pain Management
secondary_outcome.description: Resource utilization was defined as the number of additional visits including additional telephone visits during the treatment period. This was assessed at week 24.

intervention.description: 8 to 32 mg once daily for 52 weeks (flexible dosing)
10, 20, or 40 mg twice a day for 52 weeks (flexible dosing)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients with chronic noncancer pain severe enough to require continuous opioid therapy (a score of at least 5 in "pain right now" on a 11 point numeric rating scale) who have never received an opioid or are currently treated with a weak opioid, and who experience insufficient pain control.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have been treated with strong opioids (including hydromorphone and oxycodone) within the last 4 weeks prior to study inclusion or who will probably undergo any treatment (e.g. neurological techniques, surgery) within the next 6 months, which may abruptly alter degree or nature of pain experienced
- patients with a history of disease(s), current illness, or therapy which would preclude them from participation in the study
- and patients who are pregnant or nursing.

results_reference.citation: Binsfeld H, Szczepanski L, Waechter S, Richarz U, Sabatowski R. A randomized study to demonstrate noninferiority of once-daily OROS(®) hydromorphone with twice-daily sustained-release oxycodone for moderate to severe chronic noncancer pain. Pain Pract. 2010 Sep-Oct;10(5):404-15. doi: 10.1111/j.1533-2500.2009.00342.x.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Study conducted in 11 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, Poland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, and Switzerland). 63 study centres randomized subjects and 1 centre screened 1 subject but did not randomize. Recruitment period: 15 March 2006 (first patient in) to 31 March 2007 (last patient in).

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Per Protocol [PP] Population)
outcome.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with sustained release (SR) oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".
outcome.population: PP population (all randomized subjects who took the study medication at least once, who had post-baseline efficacy data, and who were without major protocol violation)

group.title: OROS Hydromorphone HCl
group.description: Initial dose 8 mg (minimum dose), 16 mg, or 32 mg (maximum dose), oral administration, once-daily, 4 weeks (titration phase), 20 weeks (maintenance phase), 28 weeks (extension phase)

group.title: Oxycodone
group.description: Initial dose 10 mg (minimum dose), 20 mg, and 40 mg, oral administration, twice daily, 4 weeks (titration phase), 20 weeks (maintenance phase), and 28 weeks (extension phase)

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Per Protocol [PP] Population)
measure.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with sustained release (SR) oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".
measure.population: PP population (all randomized subjects who took the study medication at least once, who had post-baseline efficacy data, and who were without major protocol violation)

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: Difference in change from baseline with OROS hydromorphone compared with SR oxycodone was less than or equal to 1. Alternative hypothesis: Difference in change from baseline with OROS hydromorphone compared with SR oxycodone was greater than 1. Sample size needed to detect a clinically significant difference of 1 was 151 per treatment arm (standard deviation = 2.4, significance level 0.025 one-sided, based on 90% power).
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Tested using 95% confidence interval approach. The non-inferiority margin was 1.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical significance level was 0.05. Two-sided 95% CI of the treatment difference based on LS means & error terms obtained from ANCOVA (covariate: baseline; factors: country, previous pain treatment, underlying disease, and treatment).
analysis.method_desc: If the right side of CI<1 then the null hypothesis was rejected in favour of the alternative, and non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was concluded.
analysis.estimate_desc: LS mean difference has been presented, which was calculated as hydromorphone minus oxycodone.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Pain Severity Sub-score "Pain at Its Worst" (BPI Item 3) at Week 24 (ITT Population)
outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in BPI pain severity, pain at its worst (BPI item 3) assessed using the BPI questionnaire. Score values ranges from 0 (no pain) to 10 (pain as bad as you can imagine). Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain at its worst".
outcome.population: ITT population (all randomized subjects who took the study medication at least once, excluding subjects who had no post-baseline efficacy data)

measure.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Pain Severity Sub-score "Pain at Its Worst" (BPI Item 3) at Week 24 (ITT Population)

measure.population: ITT population (all randomized subjects who took the study medication at least once, excluding subjects who had no post-baseline efficacy data)

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: Difference in change from baseline between hydromorphone and oxycodone was equal to zero. Alternative hypothesis: Difference in change from baseline between hydromorphone and oxycodone was not equal to zero.
analysis.p_value_desc: A two-sided significance level of 0.05 was used. A closed hierarchical testing procedure was used to control the overall Type I error. Procedure was stopped here, subsequent tests were exploratory in nature.
analysis.method_desc: Superiority of OROS hydromorphone compared to SR oxycodone was evaluated.
analysis.estimate_desc: Mean difference calculated: hydromorphone minus oxycodone

outcome.description: Change from baseline in pain severity, pain relief, and pain interference was assessed using the BPI questionnaire at week 52. BPI items 3 to 6, score range 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine; BPI items 9a to 9g, score range from 0 to 10, where 0 = does not interfere and 10 = completely interferes. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain severity and pain interference. BPI item 8, score range from 0 to 100, where 0 = no relief and 100 = complete relief. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain relief.

outcome.title: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (PP Population)
outcome.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.
outcome.population: PP population (all subjects who took the study medication at least once, who had post-baseline efficacy data, and who were without major protocol violation)

group.description: Initial dose 10 mg (minimum dose), 20 mg, and 40 mg, oral administration, twice daily, 4 weeks (titration phase), 20 weeks (maintenance phase), and 28 weeks (extension phase)

measure.title: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (PP Population)
measure.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.
measure.population: PP population (all subjects who took the study medication at least once, who had post-baseline efficacy data, and who were without major protocol violation)

outcome.title: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (ITT Population)
outcome.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.
outcome.population: ITT population (all randomized subjects who took the study medication at least once, excluding subjects who had no post-baseline efficacy data)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
